tutorial.title: Interactive Image Gallery
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use JavaScript to create upvote and downvote buttons

executableContent.instructions:
Let's build an interactive image gallery that displays a large, main photo and a series of thumbnails.

First, take a moment to examine the provided code. Pay particular attention to the image gallery HTML structure and the image element IDs.

When viewing the image gallery, users should be able to select a thumbnail to view as the main image. Let's begin by declaring a function that takes the clicked-upon thumbnail's `id` as a parameter. By passing the thumbnail `id`, we'll be able to change the main image to whichever thumbnail image the user clicks. 

1. Declare a function `setMainImage()`, which should take a single parameter: `id`.

files.name: index.html
style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Now, let's set variables in our function to query and save references to the elements we want to manipulate. 

1. First, query the `document` for the `#mainImage` element and store its reference in a variable named `mainImage`.
2. Next, query the `document` for the `#thumbnail` with the associated `id`, matching the format of the thumbnail `id` s in the HTML file. Store its reference in a variable named `thumbnail`.

files.name: index.html
style.css
script.js
files.content: function setMainImage(id) {}

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: For the `thumbnail` variable, you'll need to concatenate a string with the `id` parameter to appropriately target the element. The `id` parameter will be an integer corresponding to the thumbnail number, so you'll need to concatenate `"#thumbnail"` with the `id` parameter. For example, calling the function with the argument`3` should store the value `#thumbnail3` in the `thumbnail` variable.

executableContent.instructions:
In order to dynamically set the main image to the image a user clicks, we'll need to get the `src` attribute of the selected thumbnail image.

1. Create a variable named `thumbnailSrc`.
2. Use the appropriate JavaScript function to get the `src` attribute of the selected thumbnail and store it in the `thumbnailSrc` variable.

files.name: index.html
style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
So far, we have saved references to the `mainImage` and `thumbnail` elements as well as the `thumbnail` image's `src` attribute. As mentioned before, calling this function should set the `mainImage` to the clicked-upon thumbnail. Let's now code this functionality. 

1. Use the appropriate JavaScript function to set the `src` attribute of the `mainImage` to the value stored in the `thumbnailSrc` variable.

files.name: index.html
style.css
script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use the `setAttribute` function, which can take two parameters: attribute name and value.

executableContent.instructions:
We want to call the `setMainImage()` function when a thumbnail is clicked. To do so, add an `onclick` event listener to each thumbnail image in the `HTML` file so that it calls our new function with the appropriate parameter. Remember, you should pass an integer corresponding to the thumbnail `id`.

When finished, clicking on the thumbnails should change the main image. Give it a try!

1. Add an `onclick` event listener to each thumbnail image element that calls the `setMainImage()` function with the appropriate parameter. When finished, try interacting with the gallery to check your work.

files.name: index.html
style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Our gallery is now interactive, but we need to apply a border to the clicked-upon thumbnail.

1. Use the appropriate JavaScript function to add the CSS class `border` to the selected `thumbnail` element.

files.name: index.html
style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Clicking on thumbnails adds a border, but we still need to remove the existing border. As the final step of this project, let's work on writing a function to clear the `border` CSS class from all thumbnail elements. We'll call this function before adding the border when a thumbnail is clicked. 

1. At the top of the `script.js` file, declare a function named `clearBorders` that takes no parameters. 
2. In the function body, create a variable named `elements` and query the HTML document to store a reference to all elements with the class name `border`.

files.name: index.html
style.css
script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Next, since `.getElementsByClassName` returns an array of elements, we'll need to iterate through the `elements` and remove the `border` CSS class from each.

1. Write a `for...of` loop that iterates through the `elements` array, with each individual array entry called `element`. 
2. Then, within the body of the `for...of` loop, remove the CSS class `border` from each `element.

files.name: index.html
style.css
script.js

hints.title: Hint

executableContent.instructions:
Finally, we need to incorporate the `clearBorders()` function into the `setMainImage()` function body to clear borders from all thumbnails just before it adds a border to the clicked-upon thumbnail.

1. Call the `clearBorders()` function just before adding a border to the clicked-upon thumbnail in the `setMainImage()` function body.

style.css
script.js
